articles.content:
Psychologically, the U.N. has contributed a great deal to the gray swamp of
demoralization—of cynicism, bitterness, hopelessness, fear and nameless
guilt—which is swallowing the Western world. But the communist world has
gained a moral sanction, a stamp of civilized respectability from the Western
world—it has gained the West’s assistance in deceiving its victims—it has
gained the status and prestige of an equal partner, thus establishing the
notion that the difference between human rights and mass slaughter is merely a
difference of political opinion.
articles.attribution:
“The Anatomy of Compromise,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 148

articles.content: When an institution reaches the degree of corruption, brazen cynicism and dishonor demonstrated by the U.N. in its shameful history, to discuss it at length is to imply that its members and supporters may possibly be making an innocent error about its nature—which is no longer possible. There is no margin for error about a monstrosity that was created for the alleged purpose of preventing wars by uniting the world against any aggressor, but proceeded to unite it against any victim of aggression. The expulsion of a charter member, the Republic of China—an action forbidden by the U.N.’s own Charter—was a “moment of truth,” a naked display of the United Nations’ soul.
articles.attribution:
“The Shanghai Gesture,”
The Ayn Rand Letter, I, 14, 1
